title: Dow down more than 500 points as stocks sink amid rising Treasury yields and a Goldman earnings miss
text:
A blockbuster tech deal was also in the spotlight, after Microsoft Corp. MSFT said it had reached an agreement to acquire Activision Blizzard Inc. ATVI in an all-cash deal valued at $68.7 billion.

What are stock indexes doing?

The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA dropped 523 points, or 1.5%, to about 35,389.

The S&P 500 SPX was down almost 78 points, or 1.7%, at about 4,585.

The Nasdaq Composite COMP fell 339 points, or 2.3%, to 14,554.

Last week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite each lost ground, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq now down 5% for the year.

What's driving markets?

Stocks were trading sharply lower as Treasury yields rose in anticipation of the Federal Reserve tightening monetary policy this year.

“We're looking at a year of a totally different monetary environment,” said Sam Solem, portfolio manager for Intrepid Private Wealth, in a phone interview Tuesday. “Everyone is trying to digest what three to four Fed rate hikes look like this year.”

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y was trading around eight basis points higher Tuesday afternoon at about 1.87%, its highest level in about two years, according to FactSet data. The yield on the 2-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD02Y, which are more sensitive to Fed policy expectations, shot up 8 basis points to about 1%.

Yield-sensitive tech and other growth stocks were weighing on the Nasdaq, but “it is not all doom and gloom out there, because M&A activity is going well, and the ongoing vaccination efforts by Western governments means the soft patch in U.S. and global data could be short-lived,” said Fawad Razaqzada, analyst at ThinkMarkets, in a note.

Information technology was showing some of the biggest declines among the S&P 500 index's sectors Tuesday afternoon, according to FactSet data. Tech was down 2.2%, while the financial sector was off 2.1%.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc.GS on Tuesday said its fourth-quarter profit fell 13%, missing Wall Street estimates, in a choppy quarter for the Wall Street firm. Shares of Goldman were down around 6.6%, leading afternoon losses for the Dow Jones Industrial Average, a blue-chip gauge of the U.S. stock market.

In U.S. economic data, the New York Fed's Empire State index of business conditions nosedived to -0.7 in January from 31.9 in the prior month, reflecting fresh strains from the omicron virus and ongoing supply-chain bottlenecks.

That's a “big miss,” said Solem, and a “sign that growth is slowing.”

Crude-oil prices CL00, meanwhile, traded at their highest level since 2014 amid unrest in the Middle East after Houthi rebels in Yemen launched a drone attack on a key oil facility in Abu Dhabi. The United Arab Emirates is OPEC's third-largest producer.

West Texas Intermediate crude for February delivery CLG22 rose 1.3% Tuesday to settle at $84.94 a barrel, after gaining 6.2% last week.

“I expect energy prices to stay high and that should benefit energy equities this year,” Solem said. The S&P 500's energy sector XX:SP500EW.10 was up 0.8% in Tuesday afternoon trading while the other index's other 10 sectors were all down, according to FactSet data.

The U.S. stock market has fallen lately “largely for reasons of psychology,” according to George Ball, chairman of Sanders Morris Harris.

“The market has been fully priced, or even overextended, for well over a year now,” said Ball, in a phone interview Tuesday. Investors are now adjusting the composition of the portfolios partly on “fear of a more aggressive Fed,” whether that proves “economically significant” or not. 

“It's not the impact of the Fed itself,” he said. “It's the fear of what an investor thinks other investors will read into the tea leaves.”

Which companies are in focus?

In its biggest ever acquisition, MicrosoftMSFT said it would pay $95 per ActivisionATVI share to create the world's third-biggest gaming company measured by revenue, behind Tencent and Sony. Microsoft shares fell around 1.9%, while Activision surged about 26.5%.

Other videogame companies also jumped, with Electronic Arts Inc.EA up 3.9% and Take-Two Interactive Software Inc.TTWO rising 1.4%.

Shares of Charles Schwab Corp.SCHW fell 3.6% after the online brokerage reported earnings and revenue that came in below Wall Street forecasts.

Shares of Plexus Corp.PLXS dropped 8% after the electronic manufacturing services company warned that it will miss fiscal first-quarter profit and revenue guidance provided in October because of “unanticipated” supply chain challenges that worsened in the finals weeks of the quarter.

How are other assets faring?

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, rose 0.5%.

Gold futures GC00GCG22 edged 0.2% lower to settle at $1,812.40 an ounce.

The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP closed 1% lower, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX fell 0.6%.

The Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP rose 0.8%, while the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI fell 0.4% in Hong Kong and the Nikkei 225 JP:NIK declined 0.3%.

—Steve Goldstein contributed to this article.
